Meu primeiro review, espero ter ajudado!

PLOT: This anime involves a young boy named Tatara-san who decides to take on ballroom dancing! It focuses on him taking part of various competitions and dance lessons that made him grow as a person and dancer. As he continues to struggle... many dancers and his teacher has noticed that he has the potential to be a hell of a dancer, (a force to be reckon with). Half way through the season, a new dancer has come into the game and that has made Tatara's world be shaken even more.
CHARACTERS:
Tatara: kind, caring, novice dancer, and a bit shy. He's also a visual learner and canpicture the choreography in his mind. Tatara-san is considered to be an underdog because he started to take on dancing later and not at a young age like everyone in the industry.


Shizuku: Incredible dancer and Queen of the Ballroom. 


Kiyoharu: One of the top dancers in the competition. Before Tatara joined, Kiyoharu was seen to team up with Shizuku on the dance floor.


Gaju & Mako: Sibling-duo that are seen on the dance floor. Mako wanted to join with Gaju, but Gaju was hesitant of it back in the day. He didn't like teaming up with her because he is constantly annoyed and underestimated with her abilities. Mako's personality is similar with Tatara. They are kind, quiet and are considered as a underdog in the world of dance.


Chinatsu: A young student in the same class as Tatara. She was once a dancer but decided to give it up. She has a mean attitude but is very kind. In the dance floor, she is more a leader than a follower.


OVERALL: One of my favourite animes to watch this year. The world of ballroom dancing has opened my eyes to see a new perspective. I have a lot of respect for dancers after watching the anime. This anime has taught me that anyone can do anything they wish (as long as they NEVER give up!)

Life is filled to the brim with experiences to be had. There are so many things one can accomplish in this world that it can become easily overwhelming; a pestering question for each individual is who do they want to be in this world of overwhelming choices, what do they want to accomplish, and what are the things they can do to reach for that goal? 
Sometimes this abundance of choice can be so overwhelming that it's hard to choose. It's hard for one to determine what they love enough to pour themselves into; and sometimes you might not feel a deep connection with anyone activity. The start of this anime conveys that exact thematic element when we are introduced to our main character Tatara. Tatara shares with the audience one of the many human barriers we face as we grow and learn to understand ourselves; not knowing what he wants to do, or where his place may fall in the world. He starts out apathetic, unmotivated, and not having a particular preference for any path in life. 


This is when Tatara finds dance. In a more specific depiction; Competitive Ballroom Dance. Through dance Tatara is able to find himself, to better understand others; and to immerse himself in a world more vibrant and colorful than anything he could have prior imagined. He finds his place, he finds his passion; and through it he finds his motivation to grow and not only become the best version of himself, but to help others achieve the same. 


Welcome to the Ballroom has consistently been one of my favorite shows since its release in the Summer season all the way up until the end of the Fall season. It's not only pushed its way through two seasonal bouts of anime but managed to stand above the rest consistently (at least, in my own opinion). It's because I enjoy this show so much that I decided to delete my preliminary review for it simply for the sake of being able to compose a review of the whole show; and, to start this newly composed review, I want to focus on my favorite part of this show: the characters.


The characters in Welcome to the Ballroom were; in the best terminology I can think of, balanced. Competitive Ballroom Dancing is a coupled sport; meaning it involves both a man and a woman, and each must play their respective parts in order to excel. I've never seen a series that incorporates both the male and female roles so fluently; we don't simply see our lead character grow - we see his partners grow with him. We explore Tatara and what leads him to the world of dance, we experience his growth; but through the series we witness the growth of his changing partners; Shizuku, Mako, and Chinatsu as well. To be able to so thoroughly explore each character; male or female, is something I normally don't have the pleasure of experiencing in anime. I was able to fully relate to both the male and female, the lead and follow, and because of this was able to thoroughly enjoy the growth of both characters through dance. I was able to understand their world; how their worlds are different from each other; how their worlds are different from my own; and how those worlds combine in their dancing and my viewership. That's an absolute pleasure, and if I were to recommend watching this anime for any one reason in particular, it is this one.


Aside from the depth with which the characters are fleshed out; the show does not fall short on story, art, or music either. The story follows a very standard sports show format, but the pacing is phenomenal and I was left each week feeling like I wanted to see more rather than underwhelmed with any sort of lack of content. The art was beautiful, and unique - given that with the many anime I have seen this was a rare art style to come across; and the music was in given moments exceptional. To comment on the OST I'd have to say I quite enjoyed the OP and ED, as well as the compositions that made the dance segments seem all the more engaging; there were times where the music wasn't of much interest, but this complimented scenes where the music was not suppose to take the forefront of the viewers attention; and when the music was meant to take a forefront... Oh boy. 


To say the least I quite enjoyed Welcome to the Ballroom; more so than many of the sports animes I've seen because of how the characters were incorporated, and far more than I had thought I would stepping into the anime. I highly recommend this show; and I hope others can unexpectedly enjoy the world of Ballroom Dance as I have. Now stand tall (or sit up straight(?)) - "Your posture reflects how people see you" - and go watch Ballroom e Youkoso.

SPOILER FREE 
this show is another excellent show on the sport genera from production ig. before talking about the plot and characters ill talk about the animation and soundtracks, as I feel these are important to this show almost if not as much as the characters and plot (ill usually forgive bad animation/soundtracks if the story and characters are well made).
art (10/10):
I really like production ig animation. in ballroom the animation was what I expected and was just great. this kind of art style appeal to me a lot and while it's a matter of taste I don't think there will be many people ifany that will tell you the animation is bad. the only thing you might find weird is the long neck the characters have (a common thing in the dance world) and that they don't animate enough of the dance but rather more of one shots of it. I still found these one shots to be incredible and when they animate the dance it's beautiful.

another thing I liked was the fact that even when the show do some dresses that are sexy you wont feel like this is a fan service unless the show wants you too (chi-chan dance half naked and it doesn't feel at all like fan service) but rather the whole thing feel like part of the dance (as it should be) and just something natural. the art work great for the show and help the plot and characters feel smother.


sound (10/10):

ill start with the voice actors. I think they did a fine job. not too many highlights but no bad parts really. 

the soundtracks and ops are wonderful. they fit the tone of the show and of course the dance. the show's soundtracks and ops will make you want to dance too. they are really good. it help the plot feel more alive and make you more invested n it.


plot (7/10):

I don't like to go to specifics about the plot. ill say this can be really interesting and great plot at times but it has it's downfalls. at some points I didn't really care about the plot and there was this one asspull (you know what I am talking about if you seen the show). overall, not the most interesting or amazing plot but not bad.


characters (7/10):

I wont go in details here as well. let's just say it's going to be a ride. some characters are good, some mediocre and some plainly bad (not a lot though). the mains got enough development but it could have been handled better. the side characters either got really good development (best example is kugimya), bad development (best example is akira) or were just left without showing up enough or get enough development (why did you leave hongou!). overall, some characters are great some are not so great. still worth watching.


overall (8/10):

the show is quite good and I recommend you to watch it. it's not a long show and is a nice ride. don't think this show is an amazing masterpiece but is indeed worth watching.

Welcome to the Ballroom got a good deal of fanfare a couple years earlier where I did have interest in wanting to check it out thanks to its rather unique focus on ballroom dancing, until I heard reception eventually got mixed and underwhelming to what it offered up. That still had me interested in seeing what made it a mixed bag among fans considering the ballroom dancing premise had storytelling potential on paper. However as I watched the anime's 24-episode TV run, I started to see the rather glaring flaws that made the hype for it quickly fizzle out.
Welcome to the Ballroom is in essencea shounen sports anime that features its male lead taking up a sport to find meaning for himself and develop greater self-confidence in his capabilities. In spite of this rather cliched element, the premise could work if the lead's character development comes off as engaging and has likeable characters serving to support or rival him in his efforts. However, Welcome to the Ballroom has a nice number of issues with elements to this storytelling premise. As our male lead, Fujita is rather milquetoast as he is frequently unsure of himself throughout the span of the anime's run and I never got much sense that he was growing as a character as he improved his dancing skills and gained more experience within ballroom competitions. Many of the other characters are not much better as a number of them have rather obnoxious and unlikable personality traits that made relating to them difficult at many points throughout Welcome to the Ballroom.


A prominent issue with the anime is that it doesn't allow for much opportunity to see things from the perspectives of the female characters. Shizuku and Mako, for example, made for some of the more tolerable and likeable characters within the anime who had roles in supporting Fujita's growth during the first half of the anime. However, the anime devoted little time to exploring their characters and motivations, and largely focused on Fujita's training and ballroom dancing. Some have ripped the anime as being sexist for assuming it regards its female cast largely as props and usually sexual objects with some scenes featuring male characters ogling the girls and a few random service shots of female characters. While I could see where this criticism comes into play, the anime gradually breaks from this trend in later episodes. However, it still doesn't devote enough focus on female characters and trying to make the majority of its cast more likeable.


The major issue that I have with Welcome to the Ballroom though is that it doesn't really do a good job of representing what the world of competitive ballroom dancing is like. Sports titles focused on major sports like baseball, basketball, soccer, and racing are accessible to audiences since there is greater awareness of the rules and training for them, thus making them relatable to the audiences that watch the tribulations of the major characters participating in them. Competitive ballroom dancing does not fit into such accessibility, thus creating a learning curve for audiences unfamiliar with the sport to learn about elements to it like types of dancing, rules in competitions, how dance performances are judged, and how dancers train. While there is mention of elements to ballroom dancing, the anime never goes into depth on them as it is more focused on the ongoing developments of its plot and characters. Without being able to properly understand the rules and dancing styles employed for ballroom dancing, this reduces the relatability that the series could have to draw audiences into caring for the developments of its characters, who already have their issues as I highlighted above.


Overall, Welcome to the Ballroom is mostly wasted potential. While having a unique premise on paper, this is largely wasted on a mostly unlikable cast of characters, not enough focus on female characters, and doing a rather poor job of making its sport of focus accessible and relatable to audiences unfamiliar with it. Unless you have a solid understanding on what the world of competitive ballroom dancing is like, I would suggest skipping this title.

It ended. One of my favorite animes this year just ended. Uuuwwwwaaaaa.
I’m sad.
But at the same time, I’m also happy cuz I love how the series ended. And yeah, I know its an original ending. Still, it was written and supervised by the author itself, that’s why it was still so satisfying. I might say, its one of the best original ending I had ever seen. Maybe I’m kinda biased, but nah, so be it.
I really really love this anime. I enjoyed watching this every week. From the story to the long necks, I appreciate them all. I do admit, it had some flaws hereand there. Even so, it didn’t stop me from liking this anime.


Okay, I need to stop rambling how much I love this anime, and just give details as to why I love this anime. Lol.


The story, was generic at best. Its a typical sports anime premise on the surface level, and its pretty much okay. What made this series really good was the progression of the story and how it was told. If I look at this in the perspective of the people who were ‘anime only’ , I could definitely say this anime was really well-paced from beginning to end. It was consistent and the story flowed really well. But in manga reader’s perspective, I did find some flaws in the anime. There were times that the anime felt rushed and slower than usual, it was sometimes hard to watch. I agree on both perspectives, they are all reasonable arguments after all, especially the manga reader’s perspective. I was once a anime only watcher of the anime, but after reading the manga, I could definitely say that they could have done it better. I won’t spoil much and just be vague about it, there were some scenarios in the manga that I think would work out really well if it was added in the anime too. It would add more depth to the characters and add more flavor to the story. Nevertheless, I am kinda contented with how things were done in the anime. It had flaws, but its still good.


The characters were really likable. I love everyone, I couldn’t hate any character. All the characters introduced were not shallow, but instead they were really realistic and interesting. They are very relatable and as a viewer, you understand how they feel. I think I already expressed how much I love this certain character before, but I’m still going to gush over how much I love this person. Chichan is ❤ .


Yes, you read that right. Chichan is best girl. I love everything about her. She is raw, independent, hot-blooded individual. I just love her character. I also love her relationship with Tatara. It might look abusive and a bad relationship, but thats only on the surface level. They both need each other so that they can grow and become a better person and a better dancer. You know what, I just love this show. XD


Let us not forget the art and animation. To be honest, I was kinda iffy with the Haikyuu-ish artstyle & animation, the long necks and curvy curves were both not helping. But after watching it for some time, I became accustom to it and I find it fitting to the story. The exaggeration of the animation made the series more unique and entertaining. For the animation of the dance, I’m pretty much okay with everything. Dunno about you, but I have heard quite alot of noise from different viewers about the minimum animation on the dance. I don’t blame them, this is a dancesport anime after all. At least they went all out in the last episode. They animated the dance routines really well, even though its still looked exaggerated. I pretty much don’t care.


Both the OP & ED songs from the 1st cour & 2nd cour were really really good. It gave me eargasms everytime I listen to it. If I were to choose which were the best OP song, it would be the 2nd OP, “Invisible Sensation” by UNISON SQUARE GARDEN. I just loved it more than the first OP. For the best ED song, I would choose the first ED, it feels more fitting to the series compared to the 2nd ED.


Overall, the series is worth a watch. I definitely recommend this anime to everyone. I know there were some flaws here & there, but all in all, the series was very enjoyable. I might binge-watch this in the future when the I could have my own BD copy of this anime.


Thanks for reading.

For those who had seen this series, know that your enjoyment is first before the road that took you here. Whether you were looking for another Lie in April or romance On Ice, what you get here locks you into a captivating journey of young Tatara and his passion for Ballroom Dancing.
Before I go into the review, I just want to say that I appreciate the author for what she went through to get to get this far. She has a long period of health issues and it is it an honor to witness her passion as well as her flaws in the adaptation. Themanga is by no mean finished and is actually behind the anime, but this still beats out the alternate ending of Elfen Lied and Deadman Wonderland from their manga by a long shot.


Story 8/10: 

The story is as shonen as it gets, at least for a brief moment. The guy likes a girl and pursuit something that he sees himself doing and to earn the glory for his chance to be with the girl. He is shy and dorky yet  He gets a coach that is secretly, greatly famous and has a mentor to look up to. With supportive friends and families as well as rivals, he began his journey to prove to the dancefloor that he belongs. Unfortunately, this is where the shonen stops. He gets beaten, took losses and lose the ideal vision he sees in his past. He has to grow and adapt to the situation while maintaining a strong passion for his art. He gets to meet with the ugly side of dancing and loss faith in himself numerous times. Does he ever give up? Yes. However, the cast is there to lift him up and give him a helping hand every so often, even when they are not there. He helped them in return and grow a bond forged through hardship and ambition. 


Art 7.5/10:

Long Necks? Yeah, get on with it. Reusing shots after shots and moving a picture left and right for a more than a conservative amount of time? Some moments, this works. Many, do not. Otherwise, background, effects, choreography, and scenes are all nicely timed, placed, narrative executed.


Sound 9.5/10:

Classic + Classy = Casablanca. The scenes matched the feel of each track as well as the style of animation. It simply does not care about the background music played for that performance but for the scenes it portrays. Its a mixed shift, but not unwelcoming. 


Character 9/10:

As explained earlier, Tatara is annoying yet charming for any veteran anime watcher. As shown by a certain hero still in Academia, this MC is malleable for any show (or disaster) and the adaptation served as the frame that lets him blossom and blossom he did.


The cast is a strong pillar in this story, the water and soil to Tatara so to speak. Not only are they are nicely developed, but their lingering presence after their major moments still garner the attention of great importance. To give the supporting cast and Tatara a dancefloor and then let them grew just as he did with Chinatsu is nothing shorter than necessary. They don't always correspond very well with each other, but they are bound to each other and navigate their way through the world of dance. One of the major flaws of Yuri on Ice is the cast. Some very developed while other took a huge dip in the backstage. This show also balanced out the arc and make them important to all the casts and leave every episode on a very high note, for better or worst. Even the villains are just people with as much to lose as Tatara and their moment of realization and peace leaves an imprint in my mind. Even Tokyo GHoul sometimes faltered in this.


Some may argue that the characters have flaws, such as Kiyoharu's weird edgy moments and the ball being passed less to Chizuku as the show progressed. However, the later episodes have no adaptation to really draw from and the author can only do so much. Unfortunately, many people dislike Tatara for his more spineless and indecisive moments like other main anime characters. This is WRONG! It took a long time to get to, but the brief scene you see his mother leaving him shows just how much this affected him. He moved on since then, yes, but for a guy with divorced parent and a poor economic situation, his lacks of confidence are very logical. In fact, apart from those moments, the show seems to develop a good flashback for every social flaw each character expose in the series. It may not be as potent as March Comes in Like a Lion or as bloody epic as Tokyo Ghoul, but the road the characters in these series took to get to where they are is brimming with purpose. 


Enjoyment 10/10:

Why? It gets me tears rolling down and feelings spilling out. This show is classy and necessary. It is driven with passion and honesty so strong that it twists the narrative into reality. To hold my feeling so tights and grasping my needs for a dose every week, it made me feel alive. The music, art, and characters are a family worth meeting. Will it get a sequel? Will I get a sequel? Life is too cruel not to.


Recommendations: Nodame Cantabile, Your Lie in April, Yuri!! On Ice, Haikyuu, Bay Step, March Comes in like a Lion and My Hero Academia.


Overall:

10/10

It's been a while since I had the chance to see an anime like this one so, I don't know exactly where to start.
Ballroom e youkoso is an inusual sports anime, where dance is everything and the plot and character development, it's also around the ballroom dance. When I say dance i really mean it: The animation, the visuals, the music, the movement, the aesthetics, everything makes someone really feel, enjoy and live their performances, with pasion, with sadness, with anger. This may be the strong point of Ballroom (at least for me) They're terribly good at shooting emotions to the viewer with totally messedup animation full of movement, effects and dynamism. As a person that have been trought the world of academic, competitive art, I identify myself with this kind of anime. And I can say for sure that the world of art is cruel, crude and you need your guts to be prepared for a non-stop study of whatever you do. This story show us really accurately how this works, and how do people go throught it. Some of them may be kinda OP, or better said, over talented, but everyone has it's ups and downs, and well, what can I say. You have to watch this, if you like dance, better, if you don't you're gonna like it after seeing this. The conbination of the animation, the music, the world, the long-necked characters with super flexible bodies, makes Ballroom e Youkoso an anime full of thrill, the choreographies are outstanding, the characters are good enought. \n\n
The music could be much better thought, it amazes me that they didn't made a great effort to have a better soundtrack. Maybe, with an amaizing soundtrack, and less flashbacks and a little more of steps, I would totally give Ballroom e Youkoso a good 10/10.

Okay so a new anime about Ballroom dancing, sounds good right?
Well the problem is you won't see much dancing in it.
Right from the start the show begins with an attractive shounen style of  a boy who doesn't know what to do with his life and suddenly dancing becomes his ambition.
So down to the business, after a good start, the show becomes more repetitive and the art becomes really sloppy. Expect main characters to have necks longer than their heads -literally-.
Remember some shows when they had 15 minutes of talking and 5 minutes of fighting?
In this case you will see an average 3 minutes ofdancing per episode, without many dancing moves and being repetitive.\n\n
The overall story was good, the only thing that kept me from dropping it.\n\n
Characters were attractive and their introduction was good.\n\n
Art was decent and chrisp , but the animation had a lot of flaws.\n\n
For a dancing anime you expect to hear a lot of music, in this case the music was barely heard with the characters talking.\n\n
At the end, don't expect a lot from it. There aren't many dancing shows right there and this one did a fair job, but could've been better.

It has to be commended that Ballroom e Youkoso tries to do something very special and succeeds to a certain extent, using a male and female team sport the sport aspect is treated as a romance plot and the romance elements are directly tied to the sport. It's not just jumping the hurdle of using time for love interests that most sport shonen struggle with, it straight up takes elements from a romance plot and presents it with the passion and structure of a sport plot while covering most of what you want in the sport genre.
The first half works perfectly for anyone who likesany of those genres, and even better if you enjoy both. The animation is a bit choppy and they do the absurd mistake of replacing the music they are dancing to with generic anime mood music. We only get a few moments of synced animation since they somehow felt there was no need for that (less than a year after the success of Yuri on Ice)


This is a minor issue for the first half since the concepts they present in classic sport fashion keep you too busy to care. But the second half drops the previous plots and takes 5 episodes to build new characters and conflicts, with most development moments shown entirely again over the final match. The training camp arc can be perfectly skipped since you'll see it again in no time. The characters previously developed become part of the mob commenting on the new main pair (the kind of job left to secondaries or new characters in most sport shows). So you are left with a mixture of a very long clip show, people talking and still frames of something that could be dancing but doesn't reflect the points they get. The romance aspects are reduced to a tsundere couple that has to learn to fight together instead of each other, and the sport element  is pretty hard to follow since the sport itself has a very vague point system (you never know if they did good or bad until someone says outloud what happened while you were watching them frozen in time).  


In general terms the first half is a strong 8 or even a weak 9 with new and very good akes on the genre and designs that stand out and give a ton of dynamism; while the second half struggles to reach a 5. This clash really ends up hurting the overall enjoyment, not only resulting in an underwhelming ending but making you realize how poor the production values always were. 


It still managed to make me cry a couple of times, which is the biggest measure of a sport anime success. I think that an abridged movie would help a lot if a second season ever comes, but I'd recommend just reading the manga.

The series has many similarities with yuri on ice mainly due to its protagonist and his way of gaining confidence and experience. In addition this anime can be considered better than YOI since from the second part of the series improves its script with the introduction of Hiyama Chinatsu, a tsundere girl who slowly becomes lovable.
Previously emphasize that the second part is better in the argument and that is because Tatara doubts a lot in his motivation. I must add that Shizuku Hanaoka is a despicable character despite being presented as someone great, his personality is empty, outside the fact of being beautiful is uselessto endear yourself to her.\n\n
The reason why I compare this series to yuri on ice is because of the artistic section and the cast of characters, the animation looks very beautiful but it's fluid in terms of animation frames does not show us all the movements and does not bother to explain the basics of the dance (in the same way that YOI did not explain how ice skating was).

"A truly beautifull ballroom dance related anime definitely worth watching for Dance lovers...As much I suck at dancing,I always loved watching Dance shows & competitions..That being said,This is truly a praiseworthy anime that sums up the very theme of Competitive ballroom dancing as accurately as possible."😍❤️
The story is pretty simple yet very captivating & capable of keeping your attention throughout the whole storyline..The way this anime shows us the Passion,determination & love behind every dancer's life was truly amazing & realistic too..This anime solely revolves around dancing,so the romance part is kept to a bare minimum..But then again the story has just begun.👌😌
Every character isthis anime is very well written,has plenty of characters development when it comes to dancing..Every side character has their own backstories which were really good one's too..You just can't help but love most of these characters after seeing their backstories.\n
The artstyle/animation was decent enough...The character designs were elegant & beautiful.\n
The soundtracks were good too..Doesn't take too much of your attention but not too bland either..Just the kind of music you need for this kind of plot.\n
End Note-A truly enjoyable dance related anime I would definitely recommend for every dance lovers...This anime defintely deserves a second season,cause the real competition has just begun.🤘🎶\n

Joy - first emotion one gets watching this. Bringing through the idea of finding pure joy in dancing (in art in general), comes through pretty nicely, bringing with it the clear, pure emotion of healthy competition.
The energy and ideals so, had perfect vessels through which the story was brought to a nice level of entertainment, making the viewer explore more of the genre, or even (as myself), go to YT and look up as many dance videos as could bring me closer to being a dancer as the main protagonists.
To summarize, if you want a nice feeling after watching an anime, or simply need somethingto work on a lack of motivation each of us has sometimes, then please do look this up.

Did you know competitive ballroom dancing is a thing? Because I didn't.So I don't see why no one watched this show though.Since everyone was watching Made in Abyss and Kakegurui, and this show already looked like a copy of Yuri on Ice, thats probably why. But this show should not be completely forgotten about because it takes the average sports anime and twists it and turns it and adds its own special flavor and makes it stand out from sports anime in a way.
Ballroom e Youkoso(Welcome to the Ballroom) is about this guy,Fujita, getting pulled into the world of competitive dancing and tries to "bethe very best like no one ever was" but the down side to it is that he doesn't have as much experience as the others he dances with.This show features him on his journey and obstacles that he overcomes himself.The sport is competitive ballroom dancing,which means two people, the show does at different way of approaching teamwork, it doesnt matter if you're the best dancer ever as long as you have the right cooperation with your partner in both skill and looks.The show starts putting this amateur on the spotlight and afterwards he wants that feeling more and more.It is a very satisfying experience to say the least.The only problems I have with the story is probably the tone.There are times when the characters start getting deep development but then the tone turns into straight up comedy at a whiplash pace.




The animation is very interesting in a way.When it comes to the movements when the characters move quickly in dance it can get fluid at times but other times it can get choppy. When the characters are moving in slow motion, it looks very good,and when the characters are not dancing there are subtle details that describe the character through movement albeit few and far between.The foot movements are very detailed. The animation is a bit hindered by the amount of still frames used, they look nice but at times when characters talk about a couple dancing well or not well enough you can't tell the difference unless you  know what you are looking at because ballroom dancing is confusing.It's cool seeing the mirror in the studio to show two of the same area at different angles and they are carefully made. I have seen the other shows that Production IG have done especially with sports. This show is not the best to be done by them but it's still good looking. The character designs are very nice too.At the right times. When no one is dancing and it's just their regular lives going down they look like regular high school kids ripped out of a shoujo manga, but everything changes on the ballroom floor. The hairstyles kick in, the amazing looking ballroom apparel is put on and the necks become elongated.The necks are very long but it is only at certain times where the character is the basis of the entire screen.When the show needs to cut costs, it goes to reusing frames and flashbacks to scenes. The actual expressions and hairstyles are hit and miss, there are times where you have Mako who is one  of the cutest anime characters ever and in other cases you got Gaju who looks like a Doritos mascot and Masami and his partner who look like straight up drug addicts. On the bright side is was not much of a hassle to figure who I am looking at.One detail that is irrelevant but still nice to me is the detail put in when competitors get ready to dance.The tags on the companies their clothes come from. And how the females have a little dress tent when they get ready. Also seeing others put on their makeup it brings in anticipation.



The soundtrack is a mixed bag. It varies on four different occasions:Slice of Life, Drama, Ballroom Dancing , and Motivational,The dramatic part of the music is surprisingly nice. It is very ambient and foreboding and I like it. The slice of life aspect of the soundtrack does its job of not taking the spotlight because that is what the Ballroom dancing music is for. When that type of soundtrack hit's it gets good real quick but the sad part is that the majority of the time the music is switched out for this motivational music that is cheesy AF.It is just so melodramatic that you might as well take it and put it in a motivational video with some guy screaming quotes at you. That is one factor why sports anime is not my favorite to watch but everything else makes up for it because the sport in this show is so complex that the characters get affected in a way.



The main character Fujita was alright. I feel like his interest in dancing is a bit shoehorned in at the start because he is not even sure if he wants to do it but he is so passionate about it at the end of the show.He may be crap at dancing but he does a good job of observing someone else and mimicking their skill set but it's not enough.He digs himself a hole at times and he doesn't solve them because it's not necessary for a sport like this. From my interpretation of this sport in the show, It doesn't matter how hard you practice if you can't show it in such a presentable fashion with the help of your partner and that is the one hurdle that Fujita has to cross with Mako and Chinatsu.Mako is a character that had the graciousness of being focused on despite the fact she is not a main character. In the second half this girl comes from nowhere,Chinatsu, and as a character, she is an antithesis of the problem that the main character has.It is something that should be experience by you,the reader. It is worth it. The other characters get affected in a way because of Fujita's nature and his "coach",Sengoku, is useless.He has experience and is talented but he is so lazy.I am not a huge fan of him at all.And the villain who is not a villain is a bit ambivalent and is the embodiment of the convergence of Taylor Swift and Internal Conflict with hobbies .Doesn't make sense? Thats what i'm talking about.


To be honest, the characters aren't the highlight of the show, like the sport itself, each element is strong but not strong enough on it's own.This show is a commemorative effort on all sides to portray the art and the competitiveness of ballroom dancing and if you have the time and sick of watching Haikyuu or Kuroko no Basuke give this a go.You won't forget about it.

Overall-8

I forgot to mention how amazing the opening themes are, they are.

Ballrook e Youkoso has left me in a state of inspiration that, while many other anime have been able to bring me the same feeling, has never connected quite this deep before. There are many aspects of this show that really stand out, whether it's for better or for worse, but the overall production was incredibly enjoyable. The best way for me to express my exact feelings about the show would be to break it down to each MAL category. 
Story (9):
While the story of Ballroom isn't exactly revolutionary, it is something that many people can relate to on some level. It's a very typicalsports anime story line wherein the protagonist starts a sport in a new environment where they are forced to learn and adapt. Specifically, I'm reminded of the beginnings to Haikyuu and Hajime no Ippo. Our main character, Tatara, discovers dancing and becomes enthralled by the idea of it. Most viewers can immediately relate to him in the sense that neither party has much knowledge about dance, so they learn along with him. However, the story picks up and really stands out to me from other sports anime as it begins to emphasize the emotional relationships between characters and their partners. From the get-go we begin learning about couples, their individual stories and matchmaking stories alike, and grow an attachment to them that makes us want to root for them. While  dance can take up much of the screen time, I find that the story is really about discovering oneself and becoming in tune with those different from you. It's difficult to explain without reciting the synopsis or delving into character (which is for another category) so I'll move on.


Art (7):

So, as you will read from many others, the art does leave a lot to be desired. In fact, I would rate it lower if not for it's beautiful style. The facial expressions and imagery used were often incredible, but sadly, animation is an aspect of art in anime as well. The still shots due to the budget were probably unavoidable, but the way the camera cut to and from dancers and the audience was very distracting, and took a lot away from the visual immersion. This is something that could have easily been fixed through scene rearrangement, but it wasn't, and the product simply seemed sloppy at times. However, I can't say enough how gorgeous I found the style by itself. Especially nearing the end of the show, I couldn't help but gasp at the beauty of some shots. The somewhat poor animation barely took away from my enjoyment of the show.


Sound (7): 

The majority of the soundtrack was appropriate, catchy, and very pretty overall. My problem throughout the show is how the soundtrack was used. The music being danced to would suddenly be interrupted by a more tense or exciting tune, and while I can understand that choice, it takes away from the immersion, much like the art. Half the time I would see dancing, but not hear what they were dancing to. In fact, I think some of the problems with dancing animation could have been fixed if the music was kept through the scene to maintain fluidity. The way the music was used in the show was a bit painful for me, but the pieces overall were very good. 


Character (9):

The characters are the biggest part of the show for me. Tatara is clearly flawed, and much of the show is geared towards him noticing and minimizing those flaws. One big flaw he has is meekness, and how he has difficulty taking control of a situation properly. He's seen either backing off too quickly or trying to force the direction. However, he works hard so that this along with his other flaws don't get in the way of his main partner in the second half of the show. This brings me to Chinatsu, the said partner. She is also incredibly flawed, but one of those flaws is her stubbornness, which makes it difficult for her to change. She and Tatara are an interesting match because she needs strong direction, or she won't take any at all, and Tatara is not very good at giving such strong directions. The clashes between these two were very compelling, and kept me wanting more. There are also stories such as Akira's and Masami's that had me wide-eyed and glued to the screen as I was engrossed in their individual stories, neither of which are too drawn out or brushed over. I believe the character writing in this show is it's strongest point. 


Overall (8):

Though I would love to give it a higher score, I have to take into consideration how the art and music choices put me off a bit. However, I think this show is worth watching for the character development, interactions, and story alone. It was a beautiful tale of growth that inspired me to become stronger mentally and physically. Despite it's outwards appearance, I would highly recommend watching it.

One of the  strong points of ‘Ballroom e Youkoso’ the new view on the sport competition in anime. There are so many sport anime, but this one tells about sport dancing, which is not that popular. Thanks to that we can enjoy a beautiful dancing competition, we can known problems while learning something new and the hardships in creating a dance pair. 
The animation was more or less on high level. Like it is in other anime, studio was saving some money on the animation on the less important thing, however the important scenes were beautifully pampered with details and smooth animation. Than sceneswere very pleasurable for viewer eye. \n
The creators did a great job to put a technical description of the dance figure through the conversation of secondary characters, to not overwhelm the viewer. Most of figure were shown through animations which helped to visualize footwork in dance.\n
Characters creation was good. Not too much and not too shallow. MC was originally only a pushover and thanks to the meeting the professional dancer, his entire life has changing. Each of the character got their time, when we could become familiar with them.  \n
I have to admit that music was well suited to the situation, while the songs during the competition were perfectly matched to the dances performed by participants. Although the soundtrack was good, I did not remember it for a long time. On the other hand OP and ED was good and pleasant to listen, especially second OP performed by UNISON SQUARE GARDEN.\n
After watching the entire season I must say that this anime is incredible. 24 episodes were not enough, still want to watch more. Unfortunately this season come to end and what have left now is reading a manga. \n
I hope that my review turned out to be useful, despite the fact that it is my first :)

As usual in a sports genre, this anime is a good introductory piece. If you're somehow interested in dancing, do not hesitate, watch it. Also, sports genre fans should like it. 
Others, who are not into dancing or sports, probably should try it just because the theme is quite unique. The plot development tempo is good, you won't get bored, I guarantee. While the characters and their motives are quite usual for this genre, they interact in unusual ways. There is some humor too. In conclusion, you won't even notice how the episodes' number increments before you get to the end.
The animation style is abit unfamiliar. But as soon as you get used to it, you shall find that it is both smooth and dynamic. 


The music is good, and in important moments it becomes superb. 


The dancing itself is fun to watch. It is enjoyable and also you won't be confused because of any lack of understanding. Scenario will provide you with all necessary information about dancing.


I would give this title a score between 8 and 9, but due to the lack of really interesting heroes I stay with 8 for now.

this show is at meh for a while but around the end of episode 5 their was this scene and it blew me away and I must say that is definitely the purpose of the show. It doesn't put a real emphasis on animation or even sound rather it waits for the right moment and sweeps you off your feet. honestly, I cant imagine this show being for everybody but I do recommend checking it out because I didn't think it was for me, and man if it is for you you really don't want to miss it!
so let me give you some warningsjust incase their are some deal breakers. First, if you cant stand bodies that have been (slightly) exaggerated this show could be of putting the characters have long necks as is typical for dancers and they are a bit more angular than a softer looking show like haikyuu. Second the music in the dancing sections doesn't always watch the type of dance they are doing they seem to be going for a scene setting rather than what they are dancing to which was probably my biggest disappointment when watching this show. and Lastly, TEPPU IS NOT A FUCKING ANIME!!! which will probably haunt me till the day I die and how the fuck can they make an anime about competitive dancing when they haven't even made one on mma like seariosly WTF!!!


ok so the last point was just me ranting about my favorite manga but I left it in their because any chance I have to premote it I'm gonna take. overall if you can bear with a bit of mediocrity at times this show has some steller peaks that can blow you away

the story is about a boy who doesn't know what he wants to do with his life. he notices a pretty girl with more opportunities than him and later follows her to a dance studio. plot happens and he gets forced into the studio, more plot happens and he wants to dance professionally now. now this is well and all but it's obvious why they got a anime adaptation for this story. It's a complete duplicate of yuri on ice. let me explain, our main character is really good at copying what he watches what others do like yuri on ice's. also, he gets trainedby champions in the respective sport like yuri on ice's and the similarities continue from there. so, of course, I love this show that uses the same formula.


this show chooses to use something reminiscent of XXXHOLIC's art. that combined with the standard anime art we are used to from older shows. overall it's a dangerous play. It helps add mood to whats happening but it also takes away from it. I can't really pick out if I like it or not. but do their necks really need to be that long?


the music is pretty good not best of season good or close to but it's still pleasing. the voice actor does stand out that much to me either not that I don't like them. 


like I said before Tatara (main character kun) is a little op for getting good without having a lot of experience being able to do things he hasn't been taught and going with the flow very well including picking up on new partners thinking after recently starting to dance together. he constantly does things pros took a long time to learn even though he is told not to due to it not being as good as the original. this can be a bad thing for a fan base as many people want a character struggle to get up instead of just being talented. I happen to like this character. the others characters are fairly consistent even though we can't get a good read on the girl that he followed into dance and that's a good thing. She is used as a motivational tool for Tatara as the show goes on. we also have Mako and she really had a good first showing you can't help but love her. all of our other characters although side characters play a big part in a plot which other shows fail to do. they did this very well.


overall I'm loving this anime. it's not perfect. but it tells its story right and that goes a long way. 8 or 9 out of 10
